fr_reason: The first patent addresses excessive carbon dioxide emissions in hydrocarbon cracking systems during olefin production, while the second patent focuses on enhancing molten carbonate fuel cells efficiency.
fr_ours: Enhances molten carbonate fuel cells efficiency by recycling excess hydrogen from the anode exhaust for reuse in next pass, increasing utilization beyond traditional 70% to 75%.
fr_competitor: Addresses excessive carbon dioxide emissions in hydrocarbon cracking systems during olefin production by converting methane into electricity, thereby reducing overall carbon footprint
tu_reason: The first patent separates a first cracking product stream into hydrogen-rich methane and secondary streams, with the methane being converted into electricity in a fuel cell, while the second patent consists of a fuel cell and a separation unit that recycles hydrogen-rich exhaust back to the anode inlet.
tu_ours: System consists of a fuel cell and a separation unit that recycles hydrogen-rich exhaust back to the anode inlet.

fr_reason: The functional purpose of the US patent focuses on extended continuous monitoring of various physiological or biological states, while the KR patent is limited to measuring blood pressure.

sv_reason: The strategic value of the US patent lies in improving treatment outcomes, reducing healthcare costs, and increasing access to medical diagnostic capabilities by early detection of cardiovascular diseases, while the KR patent provides potential improvements in equipment size, accuracy, and portable design for better user experience.
